My sense is that this video is something of a whitewash (along the lines of the manner in which, for example, Wegener's "continental drift" was rejected for decades before finally succumbing to 1960s objective reality). Perhaps the early assessments of Melton and Schriever (1933), Johnson (1942), and Prouty (1952), et al., have been bettered by Zamora (2014) that "the conical craters were formed on ground liquefied by secondary impacts of glacier ice boulders ejected from a primary impact site somewhere on the North American ice age glacier". Seems worth a rebuttal, at least.

I have always found this mystery to be very intriguing and there is a wealth of videos speculating on the probable causes which fit the available evidence and observations. My favourite hypothesis, which wasn't mentioned here ticks all the boxes for me. We can narrow down the time frame for the bays creation to the ice age which depending which source is used does seem to line up perfectly with with the start of the Younger Dryas Period which was a period during the last age age (12.9 thousand years ago) of a sudden and large drop in global temperatures. Which also corresponds to roughly the time the north American mega fauna went extinct which was blamed on humans over hunting for the most part. Regarding the bays themselves they all share things in common such as forming in sandy spoil along the coastal plane (there are bays found elsewhere, not just the east coast see Nebraska Bays) and not on nearby bed rock, axis direction and elliptical ratio and they have overturned sand dunes on the leading edges and in some cases they actually overlap each other which implies they were all created quickly and within a short time in my opinion which also implies an impact as was one of the mentioned hypothesis. But there's no physical evidence within the bays which would match what we would see for any kind of meteor impact. Yet, all of the bays axis as you move south down the coast start to always point to the north west which if you plot the trajectories they all converge around the great lakes region which at that time would have been under kilometres of ice. So what if, a meteor coming down from the north east hit the ice sheet around the great lakes (which would not have left an actual crater because it would be impacting ice and the resulting melt would wash everything away also note this would explain a great deal of the great lakes geography). This would have sent millions of ice chunks (of varying sizes) into low orbit trajectories in a radial pattern from the point of impact and those ice chunks would come down at a low angle and when hitting sandy soil would cause an elliptical depression but ice chunks hitting bedrock would shatter and not leave any noticeable depressions. Also, since the impacters here are ice they would melt away and leave nothing but an empty depression to fill in with sand and water. I would also imagine this would be enough to devastate any large animals on the north American continent.  In my opinion this is the best hypothesis since everything observed can be explained by a series of events close to that. There are people far more qualified to explain it but I did my best XD See Antonio Zamora for a much better explanation.

I grew up in Eastern NC and probably one of the more famous of these formations is White Lake. It was called White Lake because all the white sand. It was a big regional vacation spot with the white sand beaches and there was an amusement park of sorts, with skee ball and a boardwalk. It was traditionally sort of a low key vacation home area, it was big enough and always calm so the water skiing was great. It was large enough where you could just sort of see the other side. Today I think it's even more developed. Growing up we heard the meteor story mostly, but interesting to see that the science has continued to progress on that.

I think more research should be done on the asteroid theory. The TL;DR here is that it wasn't fragments of the asteroid itself that created these bays, rather it was the ejecta (debris from Earth, or more specifically the ice shelf of the ice age launched by the asteroid as it struck the earth) that was launched up from the impact and came crashing down again. The Carolina Bays aren't the only such formations in the USA, there are also the Nebraska rainwater basins. If you measure the angle of all these basins (Carolina and Nebraska) you find that they all point to roughly the great lakes area. This suggests the asteroid or comet would have hit the ice shelf around the Saginaw area, launched ice chunks all over the USA and created all these basins. You might be wondering about all the land between the Carolinas and Nebraska that doesn't have these basins, well the answer is pretty simple if you think about it. The Appalachian mountains are much harder than the soft soil of the east coast and don't form craters very well, and west of that, the Mississippi River and it's tributaries have had thousands of years to meander and wash out the basins in the middle. Only the far east and west basins in areas of slower erosion are still showing.

Here is a link to a photo showing all of the known basins and their orientations. Notice the missing ones on the middle (as mentioned about the Appalachian mountains and Mississippi River)

https://images.app.goo.gl/hRZj1UNRR2FtzG7i7

To those suggesting that the Bays are kettle holes left when continental ice sheets were melting:
Pleistocene continental glaciation occurred only far to the NORTH of (most of) the Bay areas, covering New England, most of NY, and parts of NJ, PA and the Upper Midwest states.
Kettle holes formed north of the glacial terminus, as the continental ice sheets receded toward Canada. For example, Minneapolis-Saint Paul MN area is riddled with kettle lakes.
The thermokarst processes that presently occur in the near-arctic regions are different. But at the glacial maxima, the coastal plain regions of the Mid-Atlantic region had a much colder climate than today. Think: Boreal forest and Taiga.

I've also read speculation (among the Younger Dryas impact proponents) that the hypothesized extraterrestrial impact "pushed down" the rock strata that form the Michigan Basin (the "bulls-eye).
In Fact: In the sequence of successive sedimentary rock units that fill the Basin (ranging from early Paleozoic to Mesozoic age), each sedimentary formation THICKENS toward the center of the Basin. This indicates that the underlying crystalline basement (the deeper crust) was subsiding, more or less continuously, while each sedimentary unit was being deposited.

Finally - given the limited mechanical strength of even glacial ice - it seems implausible (on a large physical scale) that a point impact could hurl city-block-sized chunks of glacial ice - INTACT - for hundreds of miles. The ice would be pulverized/vaporized at the impact site, even before any velocity/atmospheric effect.

The are in more than just the eastern states - they extend into Nebraska and can be found in north America, south of where the ice sheet was 12,500 years ago on unconsolidated land. Unfortunately, the luminescence method has real problems with this type of structure because of the way that it was formed. This hypothesis also doesn't explain why the bays in Nebraska point the other way - in reality, they point towards the great lakes where, during the ice age, there was still ice. A chunk of space stuff (probably rock but weighing as much as it is calculated to have done, it would have had the same sort of effect whether it had been made from iron, stone or ice) hit the ice there (where it was several kilometres thick) and then vaporised like almost all of them do but the resulting explosion from all of that energy, projected many tonnes of ice in variously sized chunks into the air and above, from where they rained down onto unconsolidated ground that had just bee liquefied due to the seismic waves from the original impact, where they then produced conical cavities which then all but filled in due to the ground being fluid at that instant.
A space rock hitting some ice is a lot simpler than the explanation given in this video and Occam's Razor suggests that this is therefore more likely.
Suggested viewing is: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLmd4S3n7PlE2H5FYYASaLd-eM5DBE33Rz Antonio Zamora who has written a peer-reviewed paper on this very subject; and, regarding the evidence for there being an impact at all,
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GvYjDLl-gPs Dr Martin Sweatman, analysis of the many papers surrounding this issue, including the erroneous conclusion that are repeated in the video above.

They're basically the same thing as the thousands of 'lagoons' that dot the arid areas of Australia (and the midlands of Tasmania). At least in the Australian case, aridity has a big part to play in their formation, actually rather similar to the climatic conditions that promote the formation of badlands, aka, nutrient-poor, easily eroded soils, generally too dry to support decent plant cover that's occasionally exposed to heavy rain allowing erosive forces to shape them before they dry out again, preventing vegetation from stabilising them.

Generally in Australian cases, these form most often atop hills and higher land where there's less surrounding catchment to fill them and most sit in their own little endorheic basins atop these higher land areas. This is important because there needs to be enough catchment and heavy, sporadic rain cycles to fill them and allow the wind/wave action to shape them, but also a small enough surrounding catchment that they do not have regular inflows (which would cause them to spill and drain them, effectively destroying the formation). I noticed in the LiDAR scans that were shown of the Carolina Bays, that they too sit atop higher land areas with little to no surrounding catchment that could potentially erode outlets for them.

In Tasmania where I'm from, good examples would be lagoon complexes like the Woodstock Lagoons (just west of Longford atop an aluvial ridge), the Ellinthorpe Lagoons west of Campbell Town (in a dry rainshadow valley) and Lake Tiberias near Parattah, the largest of these features on the island. Geological maps tend to refer to these little lagoons with sandy dunes on their eastern shores as "aeolian formations" as wind it the primary factor in their shaping. Worth noting too that most of these will become somewhat saline as, being endorheic, salts eroded from the surrounding land can never leave to the ocean and builds up over millennia.

On the mainland, especially in the SW of Western Australia, they can often be seen in long chains, marking the routes of ancient rivers. These however had very different starting points, but shaped in the same way. Effectively, ancient rainfall was higher and broad meandering rivers filled the vast shallow valley floors with aluvium. As the climate dried, the rivers stopped flowing and the wind began to move these loose sands into scattered dunes that choked the original river channels. When sporadic deluges would hit the region, the water would be dammed up by the sand and cause ponds to form. These ponds would slowly be shaped by wind and waves into strings of little elliptical lakes. Just enough rainfall to fill them at times, never enough to reform the river and drain them.

Wow, you guys are covering the bay lakes!  My grandparents live on Lake Waccamaw, the biggest of the bay lakes in North Carolina which has unique chemistry thanks to a limestone bluff that keeps the water basic and promotes animal and plant diversity (~40 fish species compared to maybe half a dozen in the more acidic typical bay lakes), some unique to the lake.  One of the acidic bay lakes Lake Phelps has old Native American canoes and artifacts dating back to 11,000 years ago and younger preserved at its bottom, and scientists put the canoes back because they couldn't preserve the canoes as well as the lake did.  And a really intact whale skull from the Pleistocene dated to around 3 million years old was dug up from the bottom of Lake Waccamaw as well.

There's been a number of papers written on this unusually interesting subject - Antonio Zamora does some great recaps of the alternate, Glacial Impact hypothesis here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=npXY8mu2hhU A key point is if a medium sized meteor or comet hit a 2 mile thick glacier with a glancing blow, there'd be no crater left today after the glacier melted - but there might be secondary impacts where flying chunks of ice would hit any soft ground, and these would radiate out from the impact site - which the orientation of the Carolina Bays and the Nebraska Rainwater Basins seem to do nearly perfectly - sure it's not proof, but boy, it's a chin scratcher

The wind theory does not work.

Oval and elliptical should not be confused.
There is no single landscape with clearly elliptical depressions anywhere else in the world. Parts of Alaska, Canada and Siberia should have similar structures. But they obviously do not. There are all kinds of shapes from perfectly round to totally irregular shapes. The only thing that is extremely rare there is ellipses.
Wind can not create patterns of overlapping but otherwise undisturbed ellipses.
The length to width ratio of the bays changes depending on them being in horizoltal terrain or on slopes. Also, bays on slopes show clear signs of gravity induced deformation.
There is a second field of similar bays in the midwest, generally called Nebraska Rainwater Basins. All bays have a similiar convergence area in the Great Lakes region.

The theory that fits best to the features of the bays is, they were caused by secondary (debris) impacts after an initial impact on the iceshield that then existed in the Great Lakes region. By cosmic standards these were low velocity impacts (well below escape speed) of very low density objects. That's why their inclined impacts caused elliptical craters and no circular explosion craters. It also is the reason for finding them only on unconsolidated ground. The low density ice boulders were not able to punch deep craters into the bedrock.

There are two YT channels of researchers who have been working on documenting features of the bays for many years now. One is Dabbler's Den, the other is Antonio Zamora. They came to the same conclusion about the mechanics involved. The only thing they totally disagree about is dating. The soil dating is much closer to Dabbler's Den's bay dating attempt than to Zamora's. The theory was also published in several scientific papers in peer review journals for example by Antonio Zamora, by Richard Firestone and others.

My own idea that could help finding the truth is the following: If the impacts are real, they certainly were strong enough to destroy and totally mix up anything that had been on the surface and several meters underground a split second before the impact happened. If impacts caused the bays, there should not be any undisturbed fossil (or human made artefact) in the soil inside the bays, as deep as the impact disturbed the soil. Every fossil inside the bays should be very much older (buried deep enough to stay uneffected by the impact) or younger than the impact. If several bays were researched for fossils, the same gap in the fossil record should become visible in all of them.

The wind action forming the sand edges is totally inconsistent with the fact the similar elliptical bays are also found in NEBRASKA. The theory is that a comet hit the earth around Saginaw Bay in the Great Lakes region where there was 1 mile thick ice sheet. The impact broke the ice sheet and then the remains were displaced in a butterfly pattern creating the Carolina Bays and the Nebraska bay features. When the ellipses directions are measured they all align and point to a central impact area in the Great Lakes.

The wind action forming the sand bays over thousands of years is a very flawed and old theory but because it is unformitst and not catastrophic in nature, people have been very reluctant to look into this relatively new theory.

Wow, what an amazingly wrong conclusion. They are the remenets of a impact on the Laurentide Ice sheet at Saganah Bay, Michigan. This doesn't add up to what I have heard about them. The further north you go, the more west-east-ish they get. The further south you go, the more north-south-ish they get. Plus, this doesn't account for the bays in the midwest that face the opposite direction, running north-east to south-west rather than north-west to south-east like the ones on the coast are. The one researcher I listened to recons they were formed by a comet hitting the glacial ice around what is now the Great Lakes, launching large chunks of ice out where they landed, creating angled craters that, due to the soft, sandy soil, just filled back in due to liquifaction. And if you mark these on a map of the US, they make and arc which includes the ones in the midwest... a giant circle of them all pointing towards the direction the ice came from. But I do love you guys mentioned these because they are SO fascinating to me especially as a North Carolinian. My grandparents live in the middle of the state, far from the coast and I always thought it was odd they live off of a road called "Bayside". Look on google maps and there is a nice clean one just behind their house!!
